summary: The document is a confidential knowledgeability brief detailing the background of WASH-32615, a 52-year-old ethnic Jew and former Soviet radio broadcasting engineer. She worked at the Gorizont Television Plant in Minsk, Belarus, from 1966 to 1991, serving in roles such as timekeeper and television assembler. WASH-32615 claimed to have no security clearance and was involved only in unclassified production activities. The brief outlines her personal and professional history, including the plant's production of electrical spare parts and printed circuit boards for the military, which ceased by 1991. Following her forced retirement, she survived on a meager pension by raising food on land she purchased in 1989. The document evaluates her limited knowledge regarding the plant's operations and assesses her foreign intelligence knowledgeability.
key_findings: WASH-32615 was employed at the Gorizont Television Plant in Minsk from 1966 to 1991, with roles including timekeeper and television assembler.
The plant manufactured electrical spare parts and printed circuit boards for military use, with historical mention of Lee Harvey Oswald working there in 1959-1960.
Military production at the plant ended by 1991, leading to WASH-32615's forced retirement and reliance on a small pension and subsistence farming.
She had no security clearance and denied any involvement in classified work at the plant.
The document assesses her as having limited knowledge of the plant's operations, contributing minimally to foreign intelligence insights.
